results.headline: Review: ‘The Edge of Seventeen’ Takes Teenage Movies to a Higher Place
results.summary_short: In its raw honesty, “The Edge of Seventeen,” like “Clueless,” is among the best films about high school kids in years.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Edge of Seventeen

results.headline: Review: In ‘Off the Rails,’ an Eager Conductor Stalks New York’s Transit System
results.summary_short: Adam Irving’s documentary is the story of Darius McCollum, a man with Asperger’s syndrome who borrows trains and buses for joy rides.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Off the Rails

results.display_title: Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened
results.headline: Review: Merrily (and Ruefully) Recalling an Epic Broadway Flop
results.summary_short: “Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened,” a documentary by Lonny Price, examines the buildup and collapse of “Merrily We Roll Along” in 1981.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Best Worst Thing That Ever Could Have Happened

results.headline: Review: ‘Uncle Howard’ Looks Back at a Filmmaker’s Work Cut Short
results.summary_short: This documentary is a dual portrait of intertwined artists: Howard Brookner, who died of AIDS early in his career, and his nephew Aaron Brookner, now also a filmmaker.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Uncle Howard

results.headline: Review: A Pickpocket Is Recruited by the C.I.A. in ‘The Take’
results.summary_short: Idris Elba and Richard Madden star in this well-executed variation of the buddy-cop formula, set in Paris.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Take

results.headline: Review: ‘Ne Me Quitte Pas’ Takes 2 Alcoholics and Chronicles the Tedium of Their Lives
results.summary_short: The Belgian documentary begins with a divorce, follows a man to rehab, and includes the aftermath of an alcohol-induced auto accident.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ne Me Quitte Pas

results.headline: Review: ‘Nocturnal Animals,’ Brutality Between the Pages and Among the Fabulous
results.summary_short: This thriller, directed by Tom Ford, toggles between the life of a wealthy woman (Amy Adams) and the events in a novel she is reading by her ex-husband.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nocturnal Animals

results.headline: Review: ‘The Love Witch,’ Hell-Bent on Capturing Your Heart
results.summary_short: Anna Biller’s new film stars Samantha Robinson as a magical seductress whose charms turn out to be lethal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Love Witch

results.headline: Review: ‘Ali and Nino,’ a Love Story Set Against Majestic Backdrops
results.summary_short: During the era surrounding World War I, in the Caucasus region, a romance is complicated by religious and political boundaries.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ali and Nino

results.headline: Review: ‘Blood on the Mountain’ Looks at the Ravages of Coal Mining
results.summary_short: This documentary about the industry in West Virginia is not well made but raises timely issues.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood on the Mountain

results.headline: Review: ‘Life on the Line,’ a Plodding View of High-Wire Labor
results.summary_short: John Travolta and Kate Bosworth star in a cliché-filled drama about the men who keep power transmission lines working.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life on the Line

results.headline: Review: ‘A Street Cat Named Bob’ Helps His Owner Detox
results.summary_short: With Bob on his shoulder, a homeless busker, James, is able to face just about anything — a negligent father, street ruffians and drug withdrawal.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Street Cat Named Bob

results.headline: Review: ‘I Am Not Madame Bovary’ Takes Man Trouble to New Levels
results.summary_short: A Chinese comedic melodrama, with a divorce of convenience followed by a real jilting, has situational intrigue marred by a labored approach.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am Not Madame Bovary

results.headline: Review: ‘Magnus’ Delves Into the Life of a ‘Mozart of Chess’
results.summary_short: Even fans of chess might struggle to connect with the cursory approach to this documentary’s subject, the prodigy Magnus Carlsen, and to the game itself.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Magnus

results.headline: Review: ‘Manchester by the Sea’ and the Tides of Grief
results.summary_short: The film, written and directed by Kenneth Lonergan and starring Casey Affleck, finds a man quietly dealing with tragedies.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Manchester By the Sea

results.display_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them
results.headline: Review: ‘Fantastic Beasts’ Unleashes J.K. Rowling’s Magic on Old New York
results.summary_short: Eddie Redmayne stars as a visitor to the city with a very stuffed magic suitcase in “Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them

results.headline: Review: ‘The Illinois Parables’ Soothes and Inflames Feelings About America
results.summary_short: This hourlong essay film by Deborah Stratman juxtaposes pastoral images with a chronicle of violence, dispossession and disaster.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Illinois Parables

results.headline: Review: ‘Notes on Blindness’ Is John Hull’s Trip From Darkness to Light
results.summary_short: The documentary eloquently describes this theologian’s physical and psychological metamorphosis as he felt his vision — his past and future — fade from reach.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Notes on Blindness

results.headline: Review: ‘Hunter Gatherer’ Profiles Two Men Living on the Margins
results.summary_short: Running in place is the point of Josh Locy’s film, which spotlights the repetitive daily struggles of those with few resources beyond optimism and resolve.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hunter Gatherer

results.headline: Review: ‘Shut In’ (Naomi Watts Should Really Get Out More)
results.summary_short: Ms. Watts plays a widowed child psychologist in a big, rambling house with one boy in a vegetative state and another who may be a ghost.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shut In
